text: Thank you all for sharing your thoughts and experiences. For a certain project I’m tied to C# .Net and was wondering how to bring in a more functional touch to the UI

elements.text: Thank you all for sharing your thoughts and experiences. For a certain project I’m tied to C# .Net and was wondering how to bring in a more functional touch to the UI

text:
In C#, there is one of the oldest strong implementation of MVVM, which is WPF. It uses XAML for the template part. But maybe your know it and that is why you first ask?

In fact I discovered MVVM with a project where WPF was chosen. And I fall in love with the MVVM concept at that time. I then tried Knockout.js, and then stick to Vue.js.

elements.text:
In C#, there is one of the oldest strong implementation of MVVM, which is WPF. It uses XAML for the template part. But maybe your know it and that is why you first ask?

In fact I discovered MVVM with a project where WPF was chosen. And I fall in love with the MVVM concept at that time. I then tried Knockout.js, and then stick to Vue.js.

text: Yes we use WPF of course. I was trying to grasp or bringing together (learning)MVVM and a more functional/react gui style

elements.text: Yes we use WPF of course. I was trying to grasp or bringing together (learning)MVVM and a more functional/react gui style

text: My feeling is that it is to different way of doing things, and it seems weird to me to want to use "functional/react" way in MVVM. Let alone due to the two-way bindings which is part of MVVM.

elements.text: My feeling is that it is to different way of doing things, and it seems weird to me to want to use "functional/react" way in MVVM. Let alone due to the two-way bindings which is part of MVVM.
